item.title: Tweets about Mueller Investigation
item.description: Here’s code I used to collect a bunch of data recently. ## load rtweet library(rtweet) ## read in where left off rt <- readRDS("~/Dropbox/pgmm-all2.rds") ## search for 3 million tweets mentioning any of these keywords rt_ <- search_tweets( "papadopolous OR gates OR mueller OR manafort", n = 18000L * 10L, retryonratelimit = TRUE, max_id = max_id(rt) ) lib(warcraft) ## merge data rt <- do_call_rbind(list(rt, rt_)) ## view time series ts_plot(rt, "5 mins", trim = 1L) + theme_mwk() ## view date range range(rt$created_at) ## save saveRDS(rt, "~/Dropbox/pgmm-all2.

item.title: Intro to rtweet
item.description: Getting started with Twitter data Twitter data were already trendy, but the unpresidented 2016 U.S. election has escalated things to a fever pitch. One of the biggest drivers of the trend is the widespread availability of Twitter data. Twitter makes much of its user-generated data freely available to the public via Application Program Interfaces (APIs). APIs refer to sets of protocols and procedures for interacting with sites. Twitter maintains several APIs.
